summary.p: [1] The condition of the gravely ill Myconius worsens daily. May God restore his health!
[2] Count Georg of Württemberg came to Basel with a young, pious Count of Castelberg from Franconia [Friedrich XI of Castell], who was dispossessed by Emperor Charles V.

[3] Nicolas Perrenot, Lord of Granvelle, traveled from Freiburg im Breisgau via Breisach and Ensisheim to Thann in Burgundy. When the mayor [Hans Schirin] in Neuenburg am Rhein asked him when the Emperor would make peace, he replied, when he wishes. It was also learned from him that the Emperor had lost over 30,000 men.
[4] In Freiburg, where many mercenaries with unknown destinations are located, troops are being recruited for the Emperor.
[5] Johann Hilchen von Lorch is still in Frankfurt. They are waiting for Maximilian von Egmont, Count of Buren, [from Ulm] to return from the Emperor.
[6] The people of Strasbourg have sent Jakob Sturm and Mathis Pfarrer to the Emperor. Gast cannot yet say what they have achieved.

[7] It is said that Johann Friedrich of Saxony is marching against Margrave Albrecht Alcibiades of Brandenburg-Kulmbach and also against the Würzburg Bishop Melchior Zobel. May the Lord grant him victory! If God does not grant peace, there will be a great uprising in Christendom.

[8] It is confirmed that a farmer [...] from the village of Häsingen, a mile from Basel, has requested in writing that 80 captains be sent to his squire Hans Ludwig von Eptingen. For there are many deaths among them, and of the nine mercenaries that the squire recruited from their village, eight have already died. May all enemies of Christ and his servants perish!

div.p: Greetings in the Lord. Our Myconius is suffering from a very severe illness, which worsens with each passing day and becomes more dangerous. Therefore, pray to the Lord that He may restore him, if it is His will, and that he may regain his former health.

News: Count Georg of Württemberg is with us. He has brought with him a Count of Castelberg from Franconia, whom the Emperor has dispossessed of everything: a very pious and God-fearing man. He is still young.

Granvelle was in Freiburg, traveled through Ensisheim and Breisach to Thann in Burgundy. During lunch in Neuenburg, when the mayor asked him when the Emperor would make peace, he said the Emperor would make peace when he wishes; he also mentioned that up to the present day, the Emperor has lost more than 30,000 men.
The people of Freiburg are recruiting soldiers in the name of the Emperor. Many mercenaries are also wandering around here. I do not know where they intend to go.
Lord Johann Hilchen is still in Frankfurt. They are waiting for the return of the Count of Buren from the Emperor.
The people of Strasbourg have sent Lord Jakob Sturm and Mathis Pfarrer, the mayor, to the Emperor. I cannot yet know what they intend to accomplish.

It is said that the Elector of Saxony is marching against Margrave Albrecht, intending to fight with the Emperor's forces. May God grant victory! The Elector is also said to have attacked the Bishop of Würzburg. There will be a great uproar in Christendom if God does not bring peace.

This is certain: A farmer from Häsingen (a village a mile from Basel) has written that 80 captains should be sent to his squire, Hans Ludwig von Eptingen. He writes that there is a great mortality among them. This squire has recruited 9 mercenaries in the village. Eight have died; the ninth is still alive. May all who wish ill to Christ and His word and ministers perish! Amen. On the day of Matthias 1546. Yours, G. Greet all the brothers in the Lord.
To the well-learned Lord Heinrich Bullinger, priest in Zurich, my beloved lord. Zurich.
